_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.	Overview
CSL Behring is a pharmaceutical manufacturing facility located in Bradley IL. The facility is subject to the USEPA Chemical Accidental Prevention Provisions regulations [40 CFR 68]. More specifically, the regulations within Subpart G Risk Management Plan of the standard. CSL Behring uses anhydrous ammonia for refrigeration purposes which is a regulated chemical under the RMP rules. The site maintains a total of 193,500 pounds of ammonia between two refrigeration systems. The vessel that contains the largest volume of ammonia is the high-pressure receiver, containing approximately 43,885 pounds. The remainder of the ammonia is spread through the closed-loop ammonia refrigeration systems. 

2.	Process Description
A refrigeration system is used to reduce the temperature of a heat source. A mechanical refrigeration system is a closed system that cycles the refrigerant, ammonia, from liquid to gas and back again. As the refrigerant absorbs large amounts of heat from the source, it changes from liquid to gas/vapor. The ammonia vapor releases heat as it is condensed back into a liquid. This system is referred to as having two sides: a low pressure or low side, where the refrigerant absorbs heat as it evaporates, and a high pressure or high side, where the refrigerant vapor releases heat as it is condensed back into a liquid. The system essentially moves heat from the low side to the high side. Refrigeration for the facility is maintained by transferring heat between these two sides.  

The low side of the refrigeration system typically uses one or more evaporators to remove heat from the space or products to be cooled. An evaporator contains a set of continuous coils through which the refrigerant flows. Due to the low pressures and corresponding low temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant quickly evaporates, absorbing a great deal of heat from the surrounding area. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electr

ic fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. The low and high sides of the refrigeration system are separated by the compressor and the expansion valve. The compressor is the driving force of the system. It pulls refrigerant vapor from the evaporator (low side) at a rate that will maintain the evaporator pressure required for the desired operating temperature. At the same time, it pressurizes the warm vapor and forces it into the condenser and the high side of the system. Refrigeration compressors on the market today are screw type, reciprocating, and centrifugal.

Expansion valves regulate the flow of liquid ammonia from the high side to the low side by causing a significant pressure drop. These valves are located between the receiver (high side) and the evaporator (low side). These valves, coupled with the capacities of the compressor, can help regulate the pressure of the evaporator thereby creating the cooling capabilities of the system. The high side of the refrigeration system consists of a condenser and a receiver. Warm ammonia vapor enters the condenser after it has been pressurized by the compressor. A condenser will typically use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from this vapor, the ammonia condenses into a liquid and flows to the receiver. The receiver serves as a holding vessel for the liquid ammonia being fed to the low side. It also serves to hold the bulk of the ammonia in the system when it is not in operation.

3.	Potential Release Scenarios
CSL Behring's refrigeration system is a closed system. Historically, releases of ammonia from industrial refrigeration systems most often occur from leaking valves, malfunctioning pressure relief devices, or inadvertent releases during repair activities. 

Off-site consequence modeling was completed in 2022 by a 3rd party consultant. It consists of both a worst case and an al

ternative case release scenario for the refrigeration system at the facility. EPA's "General Guidance on Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accident Prevention" (April 2004) was used as the primary source to determine the downwind distances for each scenario. Information regarding sensitive environmental receptors was gathered from ALOHA Version 5.4.7 and Marplot 5.1.1 Mapping Software. 

3.1 Worst-case Release Scenario
A worst-Case release scenario is a release of the total quantity of ammonia from the largest vessel (High Pressure Receiver) in the ammonia refrigeration system in 10 minutes, taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity in the vessel. The receiver cannot hold the system's entire ammonia inventory as currently designed, so this amount was not assumed to be released for the worst-case scenario.

3.2 Release Duration
The first 10 minutes of the release for solutions under ambient conditions is required for estimating the off-site consequences, because the toxic component in a solution evaporates fastest during the first few minutes of a spill, when its concentration is highest.

3.3	Passive Mitigation Measures
If the largest vessel in the process is stored in an enclosure (building), the release rate to the outside atmosphere will be considerably less than if it were stored outside. In case of a release inside a building, the building can be considered to provide passive mitigation, unless: 
- The building may fail as a result of the release. This is unlikely except in the case of a large vessel in a very small room. As a rough rule of thumb, if the room volume divided by the quantity of ammonia released is less than the value of 0.1, there is a possibility that the release of ammonia will cause failures such as windows blowing out or doors blowing open. 
- The release takes place facing an opening in the building (door or windows). In this case, the door or windows will be assumed to be open, and the ammonia will be r

eleased through these openings. Since the largest vessel, the High-Pressure Receiver (HPR) is located outside, a release from the vessel would not be mitigated by the building however, there is an emergency ventilation system in place which will automatically vent the ammonia vapors to the outside. Thus, passive mitigation effects were not considered for the worst-case scenario.

3.4 Meteorological Conditions
For the worst-case scenario, a wind speed of 1.5 meters/second and stable conditions (F class stability) were used, based on EPA requirements.

3.5 Release Rate Calculations
The initial release rate is derived by dividing the total quantity released evenly over a 10-minute duration. The High-Pressure Receiver is not capable of holding the system's entire ammonia charge of 193,500 pounds. The High-Pressure Receiver only holds 43,885 lbs., therefore the Worst-case will be based off of the amount of ammonia in this vessel. In 10 minutes, the release rate of ammonia to the outside environment in the worst-case scenario is 4,388.5 pounds per minute. This release rate will be used to determine the potential downwind distance for the Worst-Case scenario.

3.6 Rural vs. Urban Topography
The local topography surrounding the facility was classified as Urban. Urban means that there are many obstacles in the area immediately surrounding the release including skyscrapers, buildings, or trees. Rural means that there are few buildings or other obstacles in the immediate area.

3.7 Estimation of Distance to Toxic Endpoint
The following source was used to identify the distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm (0.14 mg/L). The results of a 10-minute release from the Processing System's High-Pressure Receiver. The atmospheric stability class of "F" in a Urban area and a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second were considered. The distance to the toxic endpoint was found as 3.4 miles.

3.8	ALTERNATIVE-CASE RELEASE
The alternative release scenario presented is similar to the worst case

in that it is a liquid release. The alternative release scenario chosen for this facility is that of a 0.25-inch diameter orifice leading to an airborne release, representative of a pump seal leak, a gasket rupture, pinhole leak due to corrosion, flange seal leak, valve bonnet seal leak, small vessel release etc. (this is representative of many release scenarios discussed during the Process Hazard Analysis). It is assumed that this release is from the high side of the system, therefore at a maximum pressure of 150 psig. The release scenario is assumed to last approximately 60 minutes (in which time the entire charge will be released). Passive mitigation was considered for the release as some ammonia equipment is located inside of building walls.

3.9 Release Rate Calculations
For modeling the alternative release scenario, the RMP regulation allows typical meteorological conditions at the facility to be used. For the alternative release scenario, a wind speed of 3 meters/second and neutral conditions, D stability, were used. The alternate release rate is approximately 84.3 pounds per minute. Passive mitigation measures were not considered as this
release could occur outside. This release rate can then be used to determine the potential downwind distances for the alternate release scenario.

3.10 Estimation of Distance to Toxic Endpoint
There are multiple references that can be used to identify the distance to the toxic endpoint (0.14 mg/L).

3.11 Alternative Scenario Results
Input - Release Rate: 84.3 pound/min
Distance - 172 yards (0.098 miles)

4.	Release Prevention Program
The facility has considered the potential for accidental releases of ammonia, such as the potential occurrence of the worst case and alternative-release scenarios described above. In an effort to minimize the probability and severity of an ammonia release, a prevention program that satisfies RMP and OSHA Process Safety Management regulations [29 CFR 1910.119] has been implemented. The key compo

nents of the prevention program are summarized below:

· The development, documentation, and availability of critical process safety information regarding ammonia, the design basis of the system, and the equipment. This information is used in an effort to fully understand and safely operate the ammonia refrigeration systems.

· The development of an employee participation program, which includes employees throughout the organization and from a cross section of areas within the plant (i.e., production and maintenance). This program also assumes that employees that utilize the ammonia system and are most knowledgeable about it are best able to easily, effectively, and regularly recommend changes or improvements which enhance safety.

· Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) studies. CSL utilizes the HAZOP methodology for each PHA. This consists of a cross-functional team with expertise in engineering, operations, maintenance, environmental, and safety. The team performs an in-depth evaluation of the existing refrigeration system in to understand and document the risks. When risks are determined to be unacceptable, the team develops recommendations intended to enhance the safety and operability of the system. These recommendations also consider the environmental impacts.

A PHA addresses the following: 
(1)	Process related hazards 
(2)	The consequences of process control failures
(3)	A qualitative risk ranking assessment of each scenario
(4)	Engineering, administrative & personal protection  
(5)	Facility siting & Human factors
(6)	Previous incidents and near misses 
(7)	Recommendations to reduce or eliminate process related risks

PHA studies for the ammonia systems are updated and revalidated at least every 5 years. The last ammonia PHA was performed on 3/22/2024. Actions plans are in place to complete all remaining recommendations from the study.

· Written operating procedures were prepared that are designed to provide the basis for proper and safe operation of the ammonia

refrigeration system. They include procedures for normal operation, startup, shutdown, emergency operation, and emergency shutdown. They also describe safe operating limits for temperature and pressure, the consequences of operating outside these safe operating limits, and a description of safety systems and how they operate.

· Refrigeration system operators receive refresher training at least every 3 years. The training content is based upon the process safety information and operating procedures. The training program is designed to ensure that the operators understand the nature and causes of problems that may arise from system operation as well as the potential hazards particular to ammonia and the refrigeration process.

· Formal authorization systems (i.e., management of change procedure, pre-startup safety review) are in place that are designed to ensure that system changes or expansions are as safe as the original design and that an independent recheck, prior to start up, confirms that the changes are consistent with the safety, environmental, and engineering design requirements.

· Events that could potentially cause an accidental or unexpected release of ammonia are subjected to a formal investigation. The objective of the investigation is to address issues in such a way as to prevent recurrence.

· Contractors that are hired to work on, or adjacent to, the refrigeration system are "pre-qualified" based upon their knowledge of ammonia refrigeration, understanding of applicable codes and standards, and their demonstrated ability to work safely.

· Prior to the performance of any hot work (i.e., spark or flame producing operations such as welding, cutting, brazing, and grinding), management must approve the work by executing a written hot work authorization permit to verify that appropriate precautions to prevent fire have been implemented.

· Periodic walk-throughs occur to find unusual or increasing vibration, incipient leaks, corrosion, or other indicatio

ns of potential
upsets or failures that could lead to a release.

· Replacement of pressure relief valves every 5 years.

· Safety systems including pressure relief valves, monitors, ammonia vessel level controls, and safety interlocks are used in
the refrigeration system.

· Periodic inspections and calibrations are performed on liquid level sensors, atmospheric sensors, temperature and pressure instruments, switches, and shutdown devices that have safety implications.

· Periodic inspections are performed for major powered equipment, including compressors, pumps and large fans, bearings,
couplings, shaft seals, mountings, etc., for vibration or incipient mechanical failure.

· Proper design including adherence to recognized safety codes, such as the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR).

· Planning with the local fire department to ensure a rapid response to potential incidents involving the system or external
events, such as fires or tornadoes.

· Program compliance audits are performed by a third party every 3 years to verify that the elements are being properly implemented. Findings discovered in an audit are addressed with action plans in a timely matter.

5.	 Incident History
In the previous 5 years, there has been one incident relating to ammonia.

On February 19th, 2024 a ammonia delivery driver was exposed to liquid anhydrous ammonia when the purge line for the system over-pressurized and jumped out of a water container it was being purged into.  When the hose came out of the water, it sprayed ammonia towards the driver that was performing the loading process. A CSL contracted employee was observing the process within 3 to 6 feet and was exposed to ammonia vapors.  Both individuals had irritation to their eyes and were taken to the local medical facilities for evaluations.

After the event, an investigation was immediately started to determine the cause. The investigation team identified the root cause and created several actions to prev

ent the event from reoccurring. As a result, a complete redesign of the ammonia loading system was implemented. This change eliminated the need to purge ammonia into a water container and the use of a flexible purge line. The new process purges ammonia back into the closed loop system utilizing permanent piping. The standard operating procedure and job hazard analysis was reviewed and updated. Training was completed for all effected parties on the new system, job steps and personal protective equipment requirements. 

6.	Emergency Response Program
The facility has implemented a detailed written Emergency Response Plan (ERP). The ERP is intended to address emergencies at the facility in addition to incidents related to a release of ammonia. The ERP includes education and response training for employees, coordination with the local fire department, coordination with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and evacuation of the facility and surrounding area. Additionally, the plan details the procedures for: (1) pre-emergency planning; (2) emergency recognition and prevention; (3) site security and control; (4) decontamination; (5) emergency medical treatment and first aid; (6) emergency alerting and response; and (7) personal protective and emergency equipment.

CSL Behring maintains an on-site emergency response team (ERT). All members of the team participate in 40-hour HAZWOPER initial training, 8 hours of annual refresher training, annual response drills, and periodic relevant emergency response training. The CSL ERT maintains a 24/7 on-site presence to respond to facility emergencies.
